subject: Re: [PATCH v9 00/19] DCD: Add support for Dynamic Capacity Devices (DCD)

reviews.author: Ira Weiny (author)
reviews.summary: Ira Weiny reviewed patch 02/19, which adds support for Dynamic Capacity Devices (DCD), and raised concerns about the implementation of DCD configuration commands and validation of partitions.

reviews.author: Jonathan Cameron
reviews.summary: Reviewer Jonathan Cameron raised concerns about unclear behavior of cxl_verify_dcd_cmds() and suggested adding a comment to clarify its purpose. He also discussed the interface for VMs to access memory, proposing that it should be decoupled from virtio and instead use an emulated DCD device.

reviews.author: Fan Ni
reviews.summary: Reviewer Fan Ni reported a test case failure where adding DC extents to an extent list caused a dax device creation failure due to missing dax regions. They also raised questions about how the start DPA of the first region is set and how DC extents are shared among hosts with different memory configurations.

reviews.author: Alison Schofield
reviews.summary: Reviewer Alison Schofield raised a concern about three dev_dbg() messages in the cxl/extent patch, specifically that smatch complains about the types of arguments passed to these functions.

reviews.author: Dan Williams
reviews.summary: Dan Williams raised concerns about the readiness of DCD for merge, citing lack of customer pull-through and insufficient communication between platform firmware and Linux expectations.

reviews.author: Davidlohr Bueso
reviews.summary: Reviewer Davidlohr Bueso raised several technical concerns and suggested changes to patches 4, 5, 12, and 16 of the DCD patch series.

reviews.author: Gregory Price
reviews.summary: Reviewer Gregory Price raised concerns about the DCD patch, suggesting an alternative approach to region control and proposing different use cases for tags in various drivers.

reviews.author: Alireza Sanaee
reviews.summary: The reviewer, Alireza Sanaee, expressed a preference for developers to have more control over memory allocation and flexibility in their workloads, suggesting that NUMA may not provide enough flexibility.
